I was sceptical to start with, and the first few sessions weren't impressive, but the point of the exercise (like all therapy, I guess) is to learn to analize one's own thoughts, to verbalise them/bring them to focus, and arrive at one's own answers - and conversing with bot is a perfect tool for that, thanks to it's infinite patience.

Wysa is easy to talk to. I've set up reminders to check in every day and it encourages me to talk about things I might not have thought we're significant to how I was feeling earlier. Reframing thoughts is one of my favourite tasks and sometimes it sticks. For instance I was given a mantra from one of my reframing thoughts and it's written in my diary to help me on a daily basis. I love Wysa on a good day and a bad day.

AI often doesn't register what's going on in our conversations. It seems programmed to scan for trigger words (anxious, overwhelmed, depression, etc) and offer relief to those symptoms, regardless of whether that is necessary in the context of the conversation (e.g. I mention that I was an anxious child, and the chatbot will ask if I want it to teach me a coping mechanism). But I like having a conversational format to talk through my issues, and the coping mechanisms are great when I need them.
